items.content: What do you know about the United States of America? Try to answer the following questions.

content.body:
1 What name is given to the American flag?

2 Who discovered America? (last name)

3 Where can you find the Statue of Liberty?

4 Who was the first president of the USA? (first and last name)

5 When do the Americans celebrate Independence Day?

6 When were the two towers of the World Trade Center hit by a plane? (year)

7 Who becomes president of the USA if the president dies? (title, NOT name)

8 Where is the White House located?

9 Who was the civil rights leader who fought through non-violent action for the rights of the black people in America? (first and last name)

10 Who was the first person to walk on the moon? (first and last name)

11 Which president freed the slaves? (last name)

12 What are the two major political parties in the USA? and

13 Who is America's current First Lady? (first and last name)

14 What is the capital of the USA?

15 Name an American State beginning with the letter -t

items.content: Fill in the gaps by choosing the correct word from the box. There are fifteen words but only twelve gaps.

content.body:
The United States is the biggest country in the world after Russia and Canada. Alaska, the biggest of its , is about thirteen times bigger than .

The mountain range in the United States is the Rocky Mountains (often called the Rockies), which go all the way from Canada to the state of New Mexico in the south-west of the country. The mountain in the United States is not in the Rockies, however; it is Mount McKinley in Alaska.

The of the United States is called 'Stars and Stripes' because it has red and white stripes and, in the top-left corner, a blue with white stars which represent the individual states.

There are more in the United States than in any other country in the world. More than 90% of households have at least one car and the average number of cars per household is .

Joe Biden became president of the USA after winning the presidential in November 2020 as the Democratic Party . More people for him than for the Republican candidate, Donald Trump.

items.content:
Have a look at the photographs. Each picture represents a famous American landmark, an example of exceptional urban or natural beauty.

Next, read the descriptions. Each one of them matches one of the photographs.

Also, fill out the name of the state, the city or the national park that you see in the photos.

content.body:
Landmark: Picture:

In this town of glitz and glamour you'll be swept from one gorgeous highlight to the next! The bright neon lights, the hum of casinos and breath-taking shows - this is the gambling and entertainment capital of the world. Try your hand with Lady Luck at roulette or baccarat, stroll along 'the Strip', make a thrilling helicopter ride to the floor of the Grand Canyon or just absorb the atmosphere of this amazing city.

[glitz: extravagant showiness, glitter - hum: the natural noise of an insect in motion or a similar sound]

Landmark: Picture:

This is the 'City by the Bay' where we visit Union Square, Fisherman's Warf, Ghiradelli Square and the Golden Gate Bridge. We drive up to Twin Peaks for superb views. Then, as a highlight of our tour, we board a ferry for the cruise across the Bay to Alcatraz Island. Here we explore the infamous former federal prison on a self-guided audio walking tour. Hear first-hand accounts from prisoners and guards about the hard life here on 'The Rock'. In the afternoon explore the city at your own pace. Perhaps jump on a cable car and catch up on some shopping.

[infamous: having a reputation of the worst kind]

Landmark: Picture:

We travel to the world's first national park that is home to buffalo, elk and over a thousand geysers. On our tour we'll see lots of lakes, falls, hot springs, bubbling mud holes, 'paintpots' and of course, 'Old Faithful', the world's most famous geyser.

[an elk: a large deer, also known as a wapiti - a geyser: a spring that throws forth intermittent jets of heated water and steam - a mud hole: a hole filled with mud]

Landmark: Picture:

This National Park boasts the greatest concentration of stone arches in the world. Here the rocks have been sculpted by erosion into unique pillar formations called 'hoodoos', towering as high as office buildings, amazing evidence of nature at its finest.

[an arch: a curved structure, een boog - a pillar: a column or shaft, een zuil]

Landmark: Picture:

With its broad boulevards and grand public buildings this is one of the nation's great cities. On our sightseeing tour we see Arlington Cemetery, the Capitol, Supreme Court Buildings and the White House as well as the Lincoln, Washington and Jefferson Memorials. In the evening we join an illuminations tour which will highlight all the impressive monuments mentioned above.

[illumination: verlichting]

Landmark: Picture:

This is one of the great natural wonders of the world and the views are for free. Over one million gallons (4 million litres) of water per second pour over a 180 feet (60 m) high cliff that is nearly 0.6 miles (1 km) wide. The place is a great honeymoon destination for newlywed couples. Don't forget your passport because you have to view this marvel from both sides of the American-Canadian border.

[a marvel: something that causes wonder or astonishment]

Landmark: Picture:

This is a fantastic place for hiking and backpacking. It is also great for serious rock climbing on the vertical granite walls of the valley. For a short time, El Capitan was used for the dangerous sports of "base jumping" or parachuting until the park service prohibited it. The National Park also contains an impressive stand of giant sequoia trees, a ski resort and a pass over the Sierra Mountain Range to the eastern California desert.

[to prohibit: to forbid - a mountain range: een bergketen]

Landmark: Picture:

This is quite possibly the most beautiful state in the USA. The name itself is based on the Eskimo (Inuit) word meaning "great lands", which only begins to describe its near limitless coasts, countless inland waterways and great snow-capped mountain ranges.

Landmark: Picture:

This monument was completed in 1939 and is one of the largest sculptures ever created. Twenty metre high faces of four US presidents - Washington, Jefferson, Roosevelt and Lincoln - are carved into the granite mountain in precise detail. The nearby monument to Chief Crazy Horse is a work in progress and is a monument dedicated to the Native Americans. When completed, the sculpture of Chief Crazy Horse astride his pony will stand over 150 metres high and 200 metres long.

[astride: with one leg on each side / astride a horse]

Landmark: Picture:

This is truly one of the great natural wonders of the world: not just a simple canyon but rather a whole maze of canyons, fissures and gorges worn into the rock with unusual buttes, mesas and rock spires standing between them. The exposed multi-coloured sedimentary layers take on varying hues as the angles of the sun and shadows change throughout the day.

It is almost 200 miles long and about 10 to 15 miles wide. Its deepest parts along the Colorado River channel lie over one vertical mile (1.6 km) below the plateau at its rims.

[a maze: a network - a fissure: a narrow opening or crack - a gorge: a canyon - a butte: a hill or mountain with steep sides - a mesa: a terrace with an abrupt slope - a rock spire: pyramidal construction surmounting a tower, spits]

1) All the pictures above belong to American presidents. Match the pictures with the names:

George Bush - George Washington - Abraham Lincoln - Franklin D. Roosevelt - Ronald Reagan - Richard Nixon - Dwight Eisenhower - John F. Kennedy - Bill Clinton

Picture 1

Picture 2

Picture 3

Picture 5

2) Do you know some random facts about these presidents? You can use the internet to find the correct answer.

- Who abolished slavery in the USA?

- Who appeared in 53 Hollywood films?

- Who gave his name to one of the 50 states?

- Who nearly had to resign because of an affair with a White House intern?

- Who was assassinated in a Washington theater?

items.content:
Look at the following sentences:

a) If the president travels around the world, he will use his Air Force One airplane.

b) If Abraham Lincoln had stayed at home, he wouldn't have died in a theater.

c) If Trump were president, Melania would still be the First Lady of the USA.

d) If the president dies, the vice president becomes the new president.

content.body:
Which of these sentences is always true? Sentence

Which of these sentences expresses possibility? Sentence

Which of these sentences expresses improbability? Sentence

Which of these sentences expresses the fact that something didn't happen in the past? Sentence

items.content:
GRAMMAR - The Conditional tenses

ZERO conditional tense

e.g. If I drop an unboiled egg, it breaks.

> to talk about a situation that is always true

> especially used in scientific context

> IF-clause (if/when + simple present), MAIN clause (simple present)

FIRST conditional tense

e.g. If she cuts her hair, she will look completely different.

> to express real possibilities

> IF-clause (if/when + simple present), MAIN clause (will + infinitive)

SECOND conditional tense

e.g. If I were you, I would put those cookies back.

> to talk about unreal or improbable situations

> after 'if' often 'were' instead of 'was' is used

> IF-clause (if/when + simple past), MAIN clause (would + infinitive)

THIRD conditional tense

e.g. If I had studied harder, I would have passed the exam.

> to talk about things that didn't happen

> IF-clause (if/when + past perfect), MAIN clause (would have + past participle)

content.body:
1 If I (to have) enough money, I (to go) on Safari to Kenya. However, my bank account is empty!

2 I love to travel! When I (to have) enought money, I (to go) abroad. I do it almost every year.

3 I really wanted to go on Safari to Kenya with my friends but I couldn't afford to go. If I (to have) enough money, I (to go) with them.

4 I'm sorry, I didn't know you were allergic to chocolate. If I (to know) , I (to make) you a vanilla birthday cake.

5 Stop asking me what Amanda bought you for Christmas. Even if I (to know) , I (to tell - not) you.

6 If the weather is nice tomorrow, she (to walk) along the river to school.

From: http://www.englishpage.com

items.content:
Do you know the American English or British English equivalent of the following words?

First, try to fill in this exercise without looking at the list below. Maybe you already know some of these words! Afterwards, complete the exercise and choose words from the list.

content.body:
BRITISH vs. AMERICAN English

autumn -

ground floor -

FOOD

- cookies

- candy

chips -

crisps -

TRANSPORT

Underground -

- gas

- truck

pavement -

taxi -

- traffic circle

MISCELLANEOUS

rubber -

condom -

- line

- mailman

angry -

- bar

tin -

rubbish -
